title: why using `kubectl_manifest` instead of `kubernetes_manifest`?
body:
Hey there, thanks for this plugin, I've been using it _a lot_.

But! As perfect as it is, I don't really understand why we have to use 2 providers (resp. `kubernetes` and `kubectl`).
For the former, it's kinda obvious, but for the latter, why use `kubectl_manifest` instead of `kubernetes_manifest`?

Thanks a lot :)

title: Add `Certificate` resource labels
body: This adds an option to specify `Certificate` resource labels as discussed #29 . This allows to use `matchLabels` solver selector.

title: Labeling certificate manifests
body:
Labels cannot be added to the certificate manifests. This prevents from configuring [solver selectors](https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/acme/#adding-multiple-solver-types).

If this feature would be welcome, I'd more than happy to create a PR.

title: preferredChain field optional
body:
Given recently updates here: https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/pull/6755

It would useful to have the preferredChain not hardcoded to `ISRG Root X1` and make it optional/configurable within this module.

title: New typing doesn't support different solvers
Use type for variables
body:
When working with Terragrunt we encountered an issue with variables that have no type set and are being used in a for-each loop. 

See here for the error:

│ Error: Invalid dynamic for_each value
│ 
│   on main.tf line 27, in resource "helm_release" "cert_manager":
│   27:     for_each = var.additional_set
│     ├────────────────
│     │ var.additional_set is "{\"serviceAccount\":{\"name\":\"serviceAccount.annotations.eks\\\\.amazonaws\\\\.com/role-arn\",\"value\":\"arn:aws:iam::XXXXXXX:role/some-role\"}}"
│ 
│ Cannot use a string value in for_each. An iterable collection is required.

title: chore(docs): fix chart_version default
body:
👋🏻 Hello

It looks like the documentation for the `chart_version` is incorrect:

https://github.com/terraform-iaac/terraform-kubernetes-cert-manager/blob/9082a84de3969780c7acfe91f88601349028be33/variables.tf#L11-L15

title: switch to more maintained alekc/kubectl, see https://github.com/gavin…
body:
gavinbunney/kubectl seems to be no longer maintained:
for example I've stumbled upon serious issue in Kubernetes 1.27,
With the provider randomly deletes objects from the state,
See Issue: https://github.com/gavinbunney/terraform-provider-kubectl/issues/270

alekc/kubectl
https://registry.terraform.io/providers/alekc/kubectl/2.0.2

solves this issue, and keeping to maintain (currently) the provider

title: #21 Add annotations variable to certificate module.
No custom-fields can be add to the certificate
body:
I have a use case when using venafi as issuer.

My venafi is set to enforce some mandatory custom fields on each new certificate. When applying using yaml file, custom fields can be set inside metadata like this

apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1
kind: Certificate
metadata:
  name: cert-manager-xxxx
  namespace: xxxx
  annotations:
    venafi.cert-manager.io/custom-fields: |-
      [
      ]

Can we add this "custom field" feature in the module? Or can we add a way to specify a yaml file directly for certificate just like what we are doing for cluster issuer?

Thanks!

title: Unable to pass startupapicheck.podLabels within additional_set
body:
```
additional_set = [
    {
      name = "global.leaderElection.namespace"
      value = module.cert_manager.namespace
    },
    {
      name = "startupapicheck.podLabels.sidecar\\.istio\\.io/inject"
      value = false
    }
  ]
```

Retruned error is:

`Error: failed post-install: warning: Hook post-install cert-manager/templates/startupapicheck-job.yaml failed: Job in version "v1" cannot be handled as a Job: json: cannot unmarshal bool into Go struct field ObjectMeta.spec.template.metadata.labels of type string`

I've tried multiple different escape sequences, none of them have worked. 

I suppose it is related with escaping. And is related with following issue https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-helm/issues/64

Any advice how to proceed is welcome.

title: why use helm?
body:
Hi,

I wonder if you plan to rework this module to use kubectl provider directly without helm?

I guess this should be the main point of creating a terraform module for this to have a better / fine granularity control over certman resources and avoid helm overhead.

In fact terraform does what helm does only a bit better.

title: cannot init terraform with an ARM64
body:
Hey folks !
I have this issue with this module and a M1 MacOS when initializing terraform
```
Error: Incompatible provider version
 
Provider registry.terraform.io/hashicorp/template v2.2.0 does not have a package available for your current platform, darwin_arm64.
 
Provider releases are separate from Terraform CLI releases, so not all providers are available for all platforms.
Other versions of this provider may have different platforms supported.
```

Regarding Hashicorp's documentation, this is related to "template_file" that is deprecated, [follow this link](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/template/latest/docs)

Have you ever seen this and already consider a solution?

Thanks!

title: Helpful note for users of AKS/AGIC
body: Azure Kubernetes Cluster Azure Gateway Ingress Controller expects cert and secret to have the same name. If they don't it creates a cert with the name of the secret causing a variety of possible issues, in my case our secret reflector broke.

title: Swap default and type - doc fix only
body: Doc tweak

title: Bump cert-manager version
body: Regression in cert-manager v1.5.4 has caused various solvers to break, fixed in v1.7.0. Details here: https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/issues/4537

title: Add issuing certificate feature
body:
When deploying cert-manager, it can issue certificates at the same time.

The certificate module is currently intended to be used within a module but may be made into a submodule in the future.

Also, if you do not issue a certificate, you can use the module as before.

Might address https://github.com/terraform-iaac/terraform-kubernetes-cert-manager/issues/5 without being quite so rigid

Moved from data.tf & yaml file to local so users can provide solvers as structured data

title: Feature request: add dns01 into template
body:
was wondering if template could be upgrades to support dns1 configs such as 

```
apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1
kind: ClusterIssuer
metadata:
  name: letsencrypt-prod
  namespace: cert-manager
spec:
  acme:
    server: https://acme-v02.api.letsencrypt.org/directory
    email:  __cloudflareemail__
    privateKeySecretRef:
      name: letsencrypt-prod
    solvers:
    - selector:
        dnsNames:
        - '*.vinsonjewellers.com'
        - vinsonjewellers.com
      dns01:
        cloudflare:
          email: __cloudflareemail__
          apiKeySecretRef:
            name: cloudflare-api-key-secret
            key: API
```

title: Error: cert-manager failed to create kubernetes rest client for update of resource: resource [cert-manager.io/v1/ClusterIssuer] isn't valid for cluster, check the APIVersion and Kind fields are valid
body:
Hi there,

I have an eks-cluster deployed and upon applying this module. I receive this error:

> │ Error: cert-manager failed to create kubernetes rest client for update of resource: resource [cert-manager.io/v1/ClusterIssuer] isn't valid for cluster, check the APIVersion and Kind fields are valid
> │ 
> │   with module.cert_manager.kubectl_manifest.cluster_issuer[0],
> │   on .terraform/modules/cert_manager/main.tf line 42, in resource "kubectl_manifest" "cluster_issuer":
> │   42: resource "kubectl_manifest" "cluster_issuer" {

To solve the issue, I can deactivate the issuer creation `cluster_issuer_create = false` and apply a ClusterIssuer in a second step (due to dependency constraints, like discussed [here](https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1367#)).

Any chance that I can get this module working as planned?

title: "no matches for kind "ClusterIssuer" in group "cert-manager.io"" With terraform plan
body:
Hi, I am getting the following error when creating the `helm_release` for the `cert-manager` with the `ClusterIssuer` in the same `terraform apply` because the `plan` fails.

I did a bit of Googling around and it seems that it's because in the plan state, the CRDs are not yet installed so the error happens.

Is this a known issue and is there a way to circumvent it?

```hcl

│ 
│   with module.k8s_base.kubernetes_manifest.cluster_issuer,
│   on ../../modules/k8s_base/main.tf line 35, in resource "kubernetes_manifest" "cluster_issuer":
│   35: resource "kubernetes_manifest" "cluster_issuer" {
│ 
│ no matches for kind "ClusterIssuer" in group "cert-manager.io"
```

title: update istio module
body:
### Key updates include:  
**Module Enhancements:** The Istio module has been refactored for improved performance and stability. This includes better resource management and error handling.  
- Added support for proxy-protocol v2
- Added support for using Security groups with NLB

**Configuration Updates:** Several configuration parameters have been updated to align with the latest Istio best practices. This will ensure our service mesh is optimized for our specific use case.
- Added support for istio multi cluster setup parameters

title: Update hashicorp/kubernetes requirement from ~> 2.10.0 to ~> 2.30.0

Release notes

Sourced from hashicorp/kubernetes's releases.

v2.30.0

BUG FIXES:

  • data_source/kubernetes_resources: fix an issue where the provider exit with an error when the data source kubernetes_resources receives multiple Kubernetes objects containing tuples with different numbers of elements. [GH-2372]
  • kubernetes_manifest: fix issue preventing KUBE_PROXY_URL environment variable from being used in client configuration (#1733) [GH-2485]
  • resource/kubernetes_node_taint: Fix the error check for nonexistant nodes so that terraform does not fail if there is a taint in the state file for a node that has been deleted. [GH-2402]

  • Migrate legacy structure to new tfplugindocs template structure [GH-2470]

title: Unable to import module in project with Terraform 0.13.4
body:
**Describe the bug**
Unable to import module in project with Terraform 13.4 due to:

```
Error: Invalid reference from destroy provisioner

  on .terraform/modules/linkerd/crds.tf line 17, in resource "null_resource" "crds":
  17:     command = "kubectl delete -f - <<EOF\n${data.template_file.crds.rendered}\nEOF"
```

Also two warning about deprecation also are there:
```
Warning: Interpolation-only expressions are deprecated

  on .terraform/modules/linkerd/controller.tf line 216, in resource "kubernetes_deployment" "linkerd_controller":
 216:             "${local.linkerd_deployment_incoming_proxy_port}",

(and 38 more similar warnings elsewhere)

....

Warning: Quoted keywords are deprecated

  on .terraform/modules/linkerd/crds.tf line 16, in resource "null_resource" "crds":
  16:     when = "destroy"
```



**To Reproduce**
1. Put module in `tf` file
```
module "linkerd" {
  source = "git::ssh://git@github.com/rtlnl/terraform-aws-linkerd2.git?ref=main"
}
```
2. Import it
```
terraform init
```

**Expected behavior**
Possibility to import module on Terraform >=0.13.4

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macos
 - Terraform: 0.13.4

title: Cleaning up CRDs
body:
**Describe the bug**
When running `terraform destroy` or removing/commenting the module from a `main.tf` example file, the module leaves the CRDs in the cluster. This will not fail the next installation but it's not wanted behaviour

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. install the module
2. un-install the module
3. run `linkerd check --pre`
4. See error

**Expected behavior**
The module should remove the CRDs when removing the components

**Additional context**
The commands that I run to remove the CRDs is: `kubectl delete crd trafficsplits.split.smi-spec.io serviceprofiles.linkerd.io`

title: Adding Rules to Ambassador's ClusterRole
body:
We are upgrading EKS to 1.20 & ambassador requires more/different ingress permissions.

Unsure of whether to replace the other ingress rule or add it as I have done in the first commit of this PR.

Testing the upgrade process in DS Stage cluster is where I found this issue. I resolved it by manually adding the following to the ClusterRole yaml.

```
- apiGroups:
  - extensions
  - networking.k8s.io
  resources:
  - ingresses
  - ingressclasses
  verbs:
  - get
  - list
  - watch
```

title: update apiVersion used in autoscaler for kubernetes 1.16
Native prometheus
body:
Now that we're using Ambassador v1.6.0, the statsd exporter no longer works, and ambassador has a prometheus metrics endpoint by default.

This PR Removes the statsd exporter, and adds prometheus scrape configurations so that prometheus will automatically pick up our envoy metrics.

As a side note, the metrics are now waaaaaaaay nicer:
Before: `envoy_cluster_cluster_content_search_service_content_upstream_rq_200`
After: `envoy_cluster_upstream_rq{envoy_cluster_name="content_search_service", envoy_response_code="200"}`

This PR also `terrafrom` -> `terraform`

title: add container_port to configure full mapping from end to end
parametrize list of ports to enable
Fix statsd metrics exposition on the Ambassador deployment
body:
Previously, the ambassador pod had a statsd sink and was exposing prometheus metrics, but due to a misconfiguration, ambassador wasn't sending its statsd metrics to the sink, meaning they weren't being exposed to prometheus.

This commit adds the necessary configuration to make Ambassador push statsd metrics to the sink. It adds the following envars:
```Env
STATSD_ENABLED=true
STATSD_HOST=localhost
STATSD_PORT=8125
```

**Of note:** The the ambassador docs ([monitoring](https://www.getambassador.io/docs/pre-release/topics/running/statistics/) and [environment](https://www.getambassador.io/docs/pre-release/topics/running/environment/)) actually disagree on what the correct envar is to enable statsd exposition - I tried both `STATSD_ENABLED` and `USE_STATSD`, and found that only `STATSD_ENABLED` worked correctly.

Also, we technically don't need the `STATSD_PORT` envar, as it's set to the default value, but I put it there for completeness' sake.

In an attempt to fix the following error when creating the horizontal
pod autoscaler:

the HPA controller was unable to get the target's current scale: no
matches for kind "Deployment" in group ""

From what I can tell, this is caused when the referent (in this case the
deployment) version is different to what the autoscaler expects.

https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/kubernetes/r/horizontal_pod_autoscaler.html#arguments-10

Results of `kubectl describe hpa -n system-ambassador-external ambassador-external`:

```
Name:                                                  ambassador-external
Namespace:                                             system-ambassador-external
Labels:                                                <none>
Annotations:                                           <none>
CreationTimestamp:                                     Thu, 11 Jun 2020 12:57:00 +1200
Reference:                                             Deployment/ambassador-external
Metrics:                                               ( current / target )
  resource cpu on pods  (as a percentage of request):  <unknown> / 50%
Min replicas:                                          3
Max replicas:                                          6
Deployment pods:                                       0 current / 0 desired
Conditions:
  Type         Status  Reason          Message
  ----         ------  ------          -------
  AbleToScale  False   FailedGetScale  the HPA controller was unable to get the target's current scale: no matches for kind "Deployment" in group ""
Events:
  Type     Reason          Age                  From                       Message
  ----     ------          ----                 ----                       -------
  Warning  FailedGetScale  4s (x10 over 2m20s)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  no matches for kind "Deployment" in group ""
```

title: Value CEL Mapping
body:
**Problem:**

Helm's ability to construct charts from subcharts allows for distributed development to happen relatively easily.

Unfortunately, there are many cases still where constructing charts in this manner makes for user unfriendly values files. This includes duplicated values needing to be passed to multiple charts, or globals need to be very carefully crafted amongst all development parties (hard).

**Proposed Solution:**

Kubernetes is coming out with a MutatingAdmission feature, allowing CEL to be defined that can mutate the yaml on the way in.

I think we should allow charts to do the same thing.

After parsing the values.yaml and merging in the user values, the values document would be passed through CEL based mutations defined in the chart, then passed as normal to subcharts, where it also does CEL mutations for each subchart as needed.

title: Added Vault server integration for values and application specific properties
body:
This Pull Request introduces a new feature for integrating Helm with HashiCorp Vault. The feature allows users to securely retrieve secrets from Vault and use them in their Helm charts, specifically for `values.yaml` and application-specific properties files.

### Changes:
- **VaultGetter**: Added a new `VaultGetter` struct to handle retrieving data from Vault.
- **Flags**: Introduced new flags to support Vault integration:
  - `--token`: The Vault token used for authentication.
  - `--vault-address`: The address of the Vault server.
  - `--property-file`: The path to the application-specific properties file, which can be a Vault path or a local file path.
- **Methods**: Implemented methods for initializing the Vault client and fetching secrets.
- **Unit Tests**: Added unit tests for the `VaultGetter` struct to cover various scenarios, including successful retrieval, no data found, and read errors.

### Usage:
Users can specify Vault paths in their Helm charts using the `vault://` prefix. The `VaultGetter` will fetch the secrets from Vault and make them available to the Helm templates. The new flags can be used as follows:
- `--token`: Specify the Vault token for authentication.
- `--vault-address`: Specify the Vault server address.
- `--property-file`: Specify the path to the application-specific properties file, which can be a Vault path or a local file path.

### Examples:

#### Using Vault for values.yaml and properties file:
```sh
helm install mychart --values vault://secret/data/myapp/values --token my-vault-token --vault-address https://vault.example.com --property-file vault://secret/data/myapp/conf/application.properties

#### Using a local path for properties file:
helm install mychart --values vault://secret/data/myapp/values --token my-vault-token --vault-address https://vault.example.com --property-file application.properties

title: Dumping cyclic dictionaries has some serious problems
body:
Hello folks, I don't really know where to start with all this, but the story starts in a point where I accidentally created a cyclic dictionary with the `merge` operation. For simplicity's sake we can try this little example:
```yaml
# let's say this is values.yaml
inner:
  item: 0
```
I was trying to merge some defaults over to the target dict like this (it was more convoluted),
```
{{- $outer := .Values }}{{/* possibly $outer := dict "inner" (dict "item" 0) */}}
{{- $inner := $outer.inner }}
{{- $merged := merge $inner $outer }}
{{- $merged | toYaml }}
```
and didn't realize that a deeply nested value within the `$outer` dict is in fact the `$inner` dict. My target was a result like this (which I actually achieved, but not only that :slightly_smiling_face:):
```yaml
inner:
  item: 0
item: 0
```
But because `$inner` didn't yet contain any `inner` key, it has been merged in from the `$outer` dict, making it cyclic with the reference to the `$inner` dict itself. Using YAML anchors, one could write it like this:
```yaml
&inner
inner: *inner
item: 0
```
This structure is not serializable (quite naturally) by anything I tried. The problem is how that manifests:
- `toString` - results in a stack overflow crash :boom:.
- `toJson` and `toYaml` - result in an empty string (this is the worst, tbh).
- `toRawJson` and `mustToJson` - result in an proper error.
  ```
  Error: template: bug-chart/templates/test.yaml:24:32: executing "bug-chart/templates/test.yaml" at <mustToJson>: error calling mustToJson: json: unsupported value: encountered a cycle via map[string]interface {}
  ```

I'm well aware that this gets fixed by preventing the creation of the cyclic dict, e.g. with `deepCopy`:
```
{{- $merged := merge (deepCopy $inner) $outer }}
```
but that's not the point, because once I know what I'm dealing with I can easily find ways to avoid the problem. To be honest, many beginner (or I dare to say intermediate) template devs won't take cyclic dicts into consideration, especially when nothing warns them while treading these murky waters.

I see part of this criticized functionality from `sprig` (`toJson`) [is documented](https://masterminds.github.io/sprig/defaults.html) to return an empty string (`toRawJson` errs, so that's rather inconsistent with its `toJson` sibling and makes me wonder if there's any difference with the `mustToRawJson` variant).

In general, I see I want to start using the (annoyingly long, but safer) `must*` variants, but what can I do with my BFF :heart_eyes:  `toYaml`, which doesn't have a `mustToYaml`? Could that be implemented?

I must say, I'd be glad if all these operations would behave like the `must` ones, while the others would be called something like `laxToJson`, for the use cases where this (IMHO niche and potentially dangerous) functionality is actually desired. But I understand that's hardly an option for an established library as `sprig` is.

### Conclusion
- [ ] `toString` should get fixed for sure.
- [ ] Getting a `mustToYaml` would be great (I know I can use `mustToJson` as JSON is a YAML subset), but that will make the resulting k8s manifests a big eyesore.
- [ ] Updating `merge` / `mergeOverwrite` description to warn folks about the risk of creating cyclic dicts would be a really simple thing to do and would hopefully raise awareness enough so other template wizards wouldn't need to spend a day on debugging this fun.

TIA for your help!

Output of `helm version`:
```
version.BuildInfo{Version:"3.16.2", GitCommit:"5a5449dc42be07001fd5771d56429132984ab3ab", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.22.7"}
```

title: <no value> should be considered empty
body:
Returning `nil` from a template function yields a `<no value>`, which is unintuitively not considered empty.

```helm
# _helpers.tpl
---
{{- define "noval" -}}
  {{- and nil }}
{{- end -}}
```
```helm
{{- $noval := include "noval" . }}
{{- fail (print
  "empty " nil ": " (empty nil) ", "
  "empty " $noval ": " (empty $noval)
)}}
```

Current output
```
empty <nil>: true, empty <no value>: false
````
Expected output
```
empty <nil>: true, empty <no value>: true
```

---

```console
$ helm version
version.BuildInfo{Version:"3.16.2", GitCommit:"5a5449dc42be07001fd5771d56429132984ab3ab", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.23.1"}
```

title: Providing support for manually overriding dependency registry source for air-gapped environments
body:
Hi,

I would like to be able to manually override the location from which charts dependencies are pulled from when running commands like helm install or helm dependency build, i.e. requests to registry.mycompany.io/ are intercepted and forwarded to registry-mirror.mycompany.io/.

My use case for this is I have an internal registry that is accessible by all users / clusters and a mirror of this registry in an air-gapped environment, the internal registry is not accessible from within the air-gapped environment.

When a user currently tries to request a chart from the internal registry within the air-gapped environment this will fail, instead I would like these to be redirected to the mirror of the registry inside the air-gapped environment that they can talk to.

I appreciate that this could be easily handled with GitOps tooling / complicated patching with kustomise. However our users are requesting a helm native solution that would allow them to only maintain one set of charts/manifests.

I would ideally like to make the repository field for dependencies within the `Chart.yaml` file configurable via a flag that can be passed in at install / build time.

I am happy to contribute these changes myself, however I wanted your thoughts on whether this is something that you think could be integrated / supported within helm.

Please let me know your thoughts

Cheers, Jack

title: Make the authorizer and registry authorizer configurable
body:

This change makes the authorizer and registryAuthorizer of the registry client configurable via options. This allows Go SDK users to override the authentication behavior of the client.

title: helm should probably error when post renderer output is empty
body:
A post renderer executable (like the `true` command shown here) that outputs nothing but exits successfully, is not an error for `helm`.

```
$ helm install name9 chart9 --post-renderer=true
NAME: name9
LAST DEPLOYED: Thu Nov 21 16:12:39 2024
NAMESPACE: default
STATUS: deployed
REVISION: 1
NOTES:
1. Get the application URL by running these commands:
  export POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods --namespace default -l "app.kubernetes.io/name=chart9,app.kubernetes.io/instance=name9" -o jsonpath="{.items[0].metadata.name}")
  export CONTAINER_PORT=$(kubectl get pod --namespace default $POD_NAME -o jsonpath="{.spec.containers[0].ports[0].containerPort}")
  echo "Visit http://127.0.0.1:8080 to use your application"
  kubectl --namespace default port-forward $POD_NAME 8080:$CONTAINER_PORT
```

I don't know if this behavior is correct and desirable or not.

Bringing it up for others to decide.

My helm version
```
$ helm version
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.16.1", GitCommit:"5a5449dc42be07001fd5771d56429132984ab3ab", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.22.7"}
```

title: CVE-2024-21626
body:
Version: Helm v3.16.3  

AWS Security Inspector return vulnerability

Affected packages 
CVE-2024-21626 - github.com/containerd/containerd

runc is a CLI tool for spawning and running containers on Linux according to the OCI specification. In runc 1.1.11 and earlier, due to an internal file descriptor leak, an attacker could cause a newly-spawned container process (from runc exec) to have a working directory in the host filesystem namespace, allowing for a container escape by giving access to the host filesystem ("attack 2"). The same attack could be used by a malicious image to allow a container process to gain access to the host filesystem through runc run ("attack 1"). Variants of attacks 1 and 2 could be also be used to overwrite semi-arbitrary host binaries, allowing for complete container escapes ("attack 3a" and "attack 3b"). runc 1.1.12 includes patches for this issue. 

Installed version 
1.7.12

Fixed version:
1.7.13

title: CVE-2024-41110
body:
Version: Helm v3.16.3  

AWS Security Inspector return vulnerability

Affected packages	
CVE-2024-41110 - github.com/docker/docker

Moby is an open-source project created by Docker for software containerization. A security vulnerability has been detected in certain versions of Docker Engine, which could allow an attacker to bypass authorization plugins (AuthZ) under specific circumstances. The base likelihood of this being exploited is low. Using a specially-crafted API request, an Engine API client could make the daemon forward the request or response to an authorization plugin without the body. In certain circumstances, the authorization plugin may allow a request which it would have otherwise denied if the body had been forwarded to it. A security issue was discovered In 2018, where an attacker could bypass AuthZ plugins using a specially crafted API request. This could lead to unauthorized actions, including privilege escalation. Although this issue was fixed in Docker Engine v18.09.1 in January 2019, the fix was not carried forward to later major versions, resulting in a regression. Anyone who depends on authorization plugins that 

Installed version 
0.v25.0.5+incompatible

Fixed version:
27.1.1

References:
https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/13218
https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/13401

title: Don't concatenate u.Path and tag if tag is already in OCI URI
body:
Closes #13466.

If `helm template` is run for an OCI-based Helm chart, which has the tag already in the OCI URI, the download of the chart fails because of an invalid tag.

title: Error: invalid_reference: invalid tag when chart exposed as OCI url in index.yaml
body:
Running an helm command with `--repo` fails with `invalid tag` error when the selected chart is exposed as OCI url in the repository index.yaml .

```
$ helm template --repo https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami external-dns --version 8.5.1 | head
---
# Source: external-dns/templates/networkpolicy.yaml
kind: NetworkPolicy
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: release-name-external-dns
  namespace: "default"
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/instance: release-name
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm

$ helm template --repo https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami external-dns --version 8.6.0
Error: invalid_reference: invalid tag
```

These are the relevant [index.yaml](https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami/index.yaml) bits:

8.6.0

```yaml
  external-dns:
  - name: external-dns
    urls:
    - oci://registry-1.docker.io/bitnamicharts/external-dns:8.6.0
    version: 8.6.0
    ...
```

8.5.1

```yaml
  - name: external-dns
    urls:
    - https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami/external-dns-8.5.1.tgz
    version: 8.5.1
    ...
```


Output of `helm version`:

```
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.16.3", GitCommit:"cfd07493f46efc9debd9cc1b02a0961186df7fdf", GitTreeState:"dirty", GoVersion:"go1.23.3"}
```

title: Messages in `stderr` instead of `stdout`
body:
I noticed that in a lot of cases, all output of the `helm` binary appeared in `stderr` instead of `stdout`, even something like `Pulled: my-registry/helm/chart:1.1.0-1234\nDigest: sha256:a023f566d0fed443f7c745a5112c1a71c3ec9aab4127435d34256c2dc03d97cf\n` or `Login Succeeded`

It not related to the version of the kubectl or Kubernetes, it's helm binary itself.

**Step to reproduce**:
```
~/tmp$ helm registry login localhost:5000 --username=username --password=password > stdout.log 2> stderr.log
~/tmp$ cat stdout.log
~/tmp$ cat stderr.log
WARNING: Using --password via the CLI is insecure. Use --password-stdin.
Login Succeeded
~/tmp$ helm version
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.16.3", GitCommit:"cfd07493f46efc9debd9cc1b02a0961186df7fdf", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.22.7"}
```
**Expected result**:
message `Login Succeeded` in the `stdout` (when `WARNING: Using --password via the CLI is insecure. Use --password-stdin.` can be in `stderr` or `stdout`, it's doesn't matter)

**Actual result**:
message `Login Succeeded` in the `stderr`

It has the same result as any other helm command, just `helm registry login` is the easiest way to reproduce.

Output of `helm version`:

```
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.16.3", GitCommit:"cfd07493f46efc9debd9cc1b02a0961186df7fdf", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.22.7"}
```

**Output of** `kubectl version`:

Not related

**Cloud Provider/Platform (AKS, GKE, Minikube etc.**): 

Not related
